Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Medium: Collaborative Research: Multihop Multiflow Wireless Networks: A Treasure Hunt

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Wireless networks are the dominant medium through which people connect to the Internet, communicate, do business and access information. The ever-growing demand for higher data rates places the conventional approaches to network design under considerable stress. To meet this demand, future wireless networks are rapidly evolving towards high-density, user-deployed, heterogeneous infrastructure characterized by very high data rates at shorter communication range, with possibly harsh interference. In this context, multiple flow and multiple hop communication is expected to play an increasingly important role. Yet, current visions of how such networks should be designed are limited by the fact that the fundamental understanding of such novel communication paradigms is still in its infancy.

This research addresses key questions about multihop multiflow networks in the form of new ideas, insights and tools, with a transformative impact on the design of future networks. The project is organized into three symbiotic research thrusts on extensibility, side information and algorithms. In the extensibility thrust, the investigators develop a new understanding of the capacity of multihop multiflow networks of prototypical network models. The side information thrust moves beyond idealized model assumptions and incorporates imperfect or uncertain conditions at multiple spatial and temporal scales. The third thrust on algorithms translates the new key ideas developed in the first two thrusts into explicit coding and signal processing algorithms with polynomial complexity in the network size, for resource-efficient multiflow multihop communication. The research can broadly impact the wireless industry by generating new ideas that will power the design of future generations of wireless networks. The project also includes a dedicated educational plan to recruit and train under-represented minorities in this field.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to develop a fundamental understanding of multi-hop multi-flow wireless networks. Such networks are likely to play an increasingly important role in the design of future generations of wireless cellular networks which have to operate in heterogeneous environments characterized by user-deployed and user-operated components. Of particular interest were layered, two-flow, multihop networks.

 

Many new technical results were obtained that amount to concrete ideas about how layered two-flow, multi-hop wireless networks could be best designed at the physical layer. Such designs were obtained for many different settings, including ideal, realistic and pessimistic settings.

 

The best designs under idealized settings provide performance benchmarks, and pessimistic settings inform us about how even best designs perform under worst-case scenarios. There is a wide range of settings in between of realistic settings depending on various factors, such as the radio propagation environment, the mobility of terminals (such as smartphones, tablets, etc) and the sophistication of the wireless system design itself.

 

The ideal setting is one where the transmitters and relay terminals are perfectly and instantaneously made aware, through system design, of all wireless (time-varying) channel parameters over which they transmit. The most pessimistic setting investigated was one where none of the channel parameters of the outgoing channels from the relays were known at those terminals. Our investigation has shown that, in ideal settings, multi-hopping can essentially eliminate the negative impacts of interference between multiple flows of information, whereas, under the pessimistic setting, the performance of even the best designs cannot outperform even the simplest designs that involve time-sharing of the channel resources.

 

Our investigations of the realistic scenarios included questions about optimal designs when some key channel parameters are known with delay at some select combination of transmitters and/or relay terminals. We obtained methods for optimal communication under multiple such settings and provided guidelines on what architectural features must be included in the system designs to have the highest impact on performance.
